block.p: Bush Says Democrats 'Undercut' Troops in Iraq The political brinksmanship over Iraq war spending intensified, as President Bush said Democrats had ''undercut the troops'' by passing legislation that ties continued war financing to timelines for the withdrawal of American units.

Members of a Republican Congressional delegation to Iraq who were criticized by Iraqis for portraying the security situation in Baghdad as much improved said they were realistic about the dangers that remain there.
Pelosi Arrives in Syria Nancy Pelosi, the speaker of the House, arrived in Syria for a visit that is seen as part of an attempt to sway Bush administration policy on Iraq and the Middle East.

Blair Hopeful in Iran Dispute Prime Minister Tony Blair said that he was still hoping to secure through diplomatic means the release of the 15 British sailors and marines captured by Iran and that the next 48 hours would be ''fairly critical'' in resolving the dispute.

Behind the crisis of Iran's detention of the Britons lies an internal Iranian struggle pitting radicals, aligned with the president, against more pragmatic officials concerned about the country's growing isolation.

An Iranian diplomat kidnapped by men wearing uniforms of the Iraqi Security Forces was freed in Baghdad, Iraq's foreign minister said, adding he continued to work to free five other Iranians held by American military forces.

Civil Conflict Linked to Youth A study conducted by Population Action International suggests that young populations can contribute to strife. While it is not clear why, the study shows that 80 percent of the civil conflicts that broke out in the 1970s, '80s and '90s occurred in countries where at least 60 percent of the population was under 30.

A Political Stand-Off in Ukraine Prime Minister Viktor F. Yanukovich of Ukraine, above, and his cabinet resisted an order by Ukraine's president, Viktor A. Yushchenko, below, to disband Parliament, while thousands gathered near the Parliament building in support of the prime minister. The cabinet, which is loyal to Mr. Yanukovich, responded to the decree by ordering government agencies to disregard it.

France Wary of a Paperless Vote While France will be using paperless computer voting for the first time in the coming presidential election, opposition to electronic voting has grown, in part because some are made by the American company whose machines were involved in a disputed Congressional election in Florida last November.

West Seeks Water As Drought Resumes A Western drought that began in 1999 has resumed after a couple of wetter years. And some $2.5 billion in water projects are planned, the biggest expansion in the West's quest for water in decades.

McCain Delays Announcement Lagging in fund-raising and under fire for supporting the Iraq war, Senator John McCain is overhauling his presidential campaign finance operation and delaying the official announcement of his candidacy, his aides said.

Debate on Greenhouse Gases A day after the Supreme Court ruled that the federal government had the authority to regulate greenhouse gases, President Bush said he thought the measures he had taken so far were sufficient. But the court's ruling was being welcomed by Congress and the states.

Efforts to Reduce Child Obesity The Robert Wood Johnson Foundation plans to spend more than $500 million over the next five years to reverse the increase in childhood obesity, one of the largest public health initiatives ever attempted by a private philanthropy.

Romney on the Trail The Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney dashed across southern New Hampshire, enjoying the attention that has come with his fund-raising haul while trying to raise his profile among voters.
New King Documents for Sale A new cache of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s papers has surfaced for sale to the highest bidder.

Plans to House Veterans The Department of Veterans Affairs and two nonprofit groups in Los Angeles have plans to sign a long-term lease this month that will allow damaged V.A. buildings used as sets for movies and television programs to be transformed into housing with social services and counseling for disabled homeless veterans.

Democrats Seek Interview House Democrats requested a private interview with an aide to Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales who has asserted her constitutional right not to testify at a public hearing about the dismissals of United States attorneys.

New Risks in Hormone Therapy A new analysis of a large federal study of hormone therapy has found that women in their 50s do not appear to have an increased heart attack risk if they take the drugs. But women in their 60s and 70s who still had hot flashes and night sweats were at increased risk for heart attacks, even if they were not taking hormones. And if these women took hormone therapy, their risk was higher still.

New Jersey Is Diverting Billions From Pension Fund New Jersey has been diverting billions of dollars from its pension fund for state and local workers into other government purposes over the last 15 years, using a variety of unorthodox transactions authorized by the Legislature and governors from both major political parties, according to an analysis by The Times. A1

New Tower Near Ground Zero? JPMorgan Chase is in negotiations with state and New York City officials to build a 1.3 million-square-foot skyscraper near ground zero and bring thousands of employees downtown, according to officials. B1
Tennessee Wins Championship Tennessee defeated Rutgers, 59-46, to become N.C.A.A. women's champions, and Coach Pat Summitt won her seventh national title and first since 1998. D1

Vermont, a Tax Haven At conferences of the offshore insurance industry, there is often someone promoting Vermont. The state offers companies lucrative tax breaks through unusual insurance arrangements.

Pursuing the Tribune Company The news that Sam Zell is becoming the new chairman of the Tribune Company and has no plans to sell any of its individual newspapers hasn't discouraged potential buyers -- and even his rival bidders -- from planning their next move.

Russia on Global Positioning Russia and the United States are in the midst of a technological fight over America's monopoly on satellite navigation. The Russian space agency plans to launch eight satellites that would nearly complete the country's own system.

Biography on Iowa Library Cat In a hotly contested deal, the life story of Dewey, a rescued cat who lived for 19 years in a library in a small town in Iowa, has sold for about $1.25 million to Grand Central Publishing. E3
Tom Moore A president of ABC Television Network in the 1960s who helped it narrow the ratings gap with NBC and CBS, and who later won five Emmys as head of his own production company, he was 88. A13
Editorials: More than a feeling; it didn't end well last time; shackles on the AIDS program; stay on track.
